p: One experiment (in 1990) examined the antimalarial effect of A. absinthium on an animal model. Erythrocytes (1 Ã— 10 7) infected with Plasmodium berghei, the malaria-causing protozoan, were intravenously administered to mice. After seven days, the rodents were given leaf extracts of A. absinthium. The aqueous extract was given only orally, while the ethanolic extract was given orally, subcutaneously, or intraperitoneally. All the extracts produced a reduction in parasitemia, but the best inhibition effect of 96.2% was obtained with the ethanolic extract at a dose of 74 mg/kg. The results of the study showed that preparations with A. absinthium could be an effective agent in the treatment of malaria [ 79].
